review.title: A Novel Fault Classification Scheme Based on Least Square SVM
review.abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for fault classification and section identification in a series compensated transmission line based on least square support vector machine. The current signal corresponding to one-fourth of the post fault cycle is used as input to proposed modular LS-SVM classifier. The proposed scheme uses four binary classifier; three for selection of three phases and fourth for ground detection. The proposed classification scheme is found to be accurate and reliable in presence of noise as well. The simulation results validate the efficacy of proposed scheme for accurate classification of fault in a series compensated transmission line.

sections.text: The outputs of four modules of binary classifiers are used to determine the error type according to Table I. Here, + 1 represents the involvement of phase or mass in perturbations and -1 its absence. LSSVM binary classifiers are combined into a modular network of four binary classifiers, forming a multi-class classifier to distinguish between the perturbations R-G, RY-G, RYB and RYB-G.

referenceMentions.context: Least square SVM (LSSVM) is an improvement over SVM without losing its advantages [18]-[19].
Least square SVM (LSSVM) is an improvement over SVM without losing its advantages [18]-[19].
LSSVM technique for classification and non-linear regression are characterized by linear Karaush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) systems [19].
The LSSVM as a classifier differs from conventional SVM in two ways; firstly it uses equality constraints and secondly, a squared loss function is taken as error variable [19].
This section presents the application LSSVM to develop the modular multiclass classifier [20].
The LSSVM based classifier are found to perform better when trained on lesser data sets thus enabling better accuracy with lesser training data sets [18]-[19].
The LSSVM based classifier are found to perform better when trained on lesser data sets thus enabling better accuracy with lesser training data sets [18]-[19].
